B0002DB52M|5.0|I have just completed watching the three hour film and felt instantly compelled to view the reactions of fellow viewers.  To my dismay, there are many who seem to have missed even a vague understanding of its depth and meaning.   <br /> <br />I am not quite certain how to respond to this fact, so I won't.  What I will say is this:  This film is a reminder why we as a human race are so in need of stories.  Their transforming power, their capacity to relay truth and meaning to the intricate fiber of our souls; perhaps this is why Jesus Christ was so insistent on telling parables to his listeners. <br /> <br />It was this film, rather than the Passion of the Christ, which communicated such an astounding and violent reaction in me as to draw tears and physical quakes throughout my body.  How many films have done that?  For me, this is the first. <br /> <br />For this is, I believe, a Christ story.  The sweet, persistent, loving forgiveness of \\"Grace\\" amidst the self-righteous yet brutally sinful humans she is subjected to is a fairly direct parallel to the story of the Gospels.   <br /> <br />Yet there is one essential difference: the wrath this town so unquestioningly deserves, it reaps - making the forgiveness of Christ that much harder to accept.  We so rightly deserve justice, wrath, and vengeance.  It convicts us as humans of a sin so deep within us we hardly recognize it anymore.  Is \\"sin\\" even a term taken seriously today?  I don't often hear it mentioned in our political struggles or in our news of war in far-off places.   <br /> <br />There will be disagreement on this, but it deserves some diligent thought: if humankind could acknowledge this rotting sin which resides in every person, driving them to unimaginable cruelty, violence, and greed we would be a lot farther along in solving our major problems, rather than thinking up new social programs and financial solutions to bandage a gushing wound. <br /> <br />I'm not a minister or a fundamentalist Christian -I am a human being who responded in a very deep way to this work of art.  Von Trier has managed to convey a lesson about the deepest human questions we face here on earth.  These are the questions we must answer before we die.  Really, what else is there for us to do here?   <br /> <br />If you are bold enough to continue facing these questions, set aside three hours of time for yourself and you will come out an enlightened human being. <br /> <br />Von Trier deserves every ounce of praise thrown his way.  His Dogville is a moral masterpiece for the ages. <br /> <br />Let's just hope by the end of his trilogy, he will have learned these moral lessons himself.  I'll be the first in line for Part II.

B000002GJH|5.0|Having been born late enough to pretty much completely miss the 'grunge' era, and having to suffer the horrific state of late 90's 'music', I only discovered Temple of the Dog last October. <br />Whoa. <br />This is an unbelieveable achievement. If this was a debut album rather than a one-off tribute, I'd say Temple of the Dog would be emblazoned on nearly everyone's mind by now. <br />It's too bad that the reason for this album is as tragic as it is. Mother Love Bone's resident genius, Andrew Wood, OD'd on heroin. <br />It seems wrong to take such delight in what is quite clearly Chris, Stone and Jeff mourning their good friend, but when an album contains such highlights as Call Me A Dog, Times of Trouble and Say Hello to Heaven, who can resist? <br />Of course, the track most people will buy the album for (myself included) is Hunger Strike, and this song more than lives up to whatever hype you've heard. A beautiful, haunting song, tender as only Chris' lyrics can be. The wonderful vocal harmonies Chris and Eddie serve up have to be heard to be believed. <br />This album is as touching as any rock album has ever been. Don't look at it as a grunge CD, or a rock CD, or even a eulogy to a late prodigy. Look at this as the work of art it truly is.

B00005V1Y0|4.0|Baz Luhrmann made a splash with his sparkling musical \\"Moulin Rouge,\\" but before that film, he made a little splash with the colorful romantic dance film \\"Strictly Ballroom.\\" It lacks the polish of his later works, but romantics will love the ugly-duckling love story.<br /><br />Scott (Paul Mercurio) shatters a ballroom dancing contest when he suddenly breaks from routine and begins dancing his own exuberant steps. His mother (Pat Thompson) is shattered, and his diva dance partner (a very made-up Gia Carides) drops him for a champion. But Scott still wants to dance his own steps, not the rigidly prescribed ballroom dances -- even if it means he won't win.<br /><br />As he's dancing, plain Fran (Tara Morice) appears in the dance studio and begs Scott to take her as his partner -- she loved his dancing, and she wants to dance with him, even if they won't win. At first he refuses, but then he starts teaching her to dance at night. And despite the interference of potential partners and irate families, the two begin to fall in love -- and dance to set the floor on fire.<br /><br />The story is extremely simple, so much so that at times it starts repeating itself. Okay, we have the free-spirit-learns-to-be-true-to-himself, plus an ugly-duckling-falls-for-a-swan story. But it's the execution that is charming, full of color and fire and outstanding dancing. And its simplicity keeps it from feeling rushed, although the complications late in the film seem rather contrived.<br /><br />Luhrmann is known for his use of color and textured scenery, and it doesn't fail him here -- though some scenes are relatively bland, he throws in splashes of red and flashing lights, such as the giant Coke sign that flashes behind the dance partners. The ballroom competition is a spectacular opener. And the choreography is outstanding -- the actors exude sensuality and sexiness, mingled with a sort of worldly innocence.<br /><br />Paul Mercurio is an okay actor, but a spectacular dancer. It's impossible to see him dance (a mix of Latin dance, Riverdance, and breakdance) without feeling a thrill. Tara Morice, with less spectacular dancing, is excellent as the plain, awkward Fran. The secondary characters like diva dancer Liz and stage mother Shirley tend to be two-dimensional. The exception is Barry Otto as Scott's dad, who dances his own wild moves when no one is watching.<br /><br />\\"Strictly Ballroom\\" is a sweet, sensuous story about being true to oneself, about love, and about how \\"a life lived in fear is a life half lived.\\" A rough-edged gem.r. The exception is Barry Otto as Scott's dad, who dances his own wild moves when no one is watching. <br /> <br />\\"Strictly Ballroom\\" is a sweet, sensuous story about being true to oneself, about love, and about how \\"a life lived in fear is a life half lived.\\" A rough-edged gem.

B00005QGAX|4.0|After the release of \\"Thriller\\", which shot up to number one, took home so many trophies, became a staple on MTV, radio and clubs, and found it's way to more record collections than any album before, Jackson didn't rest on his laurels. He went back into the studio to record his next album, which he had high hopes for. Though it took five years for the next album to be released, it went on to have the typical high standards for a Jackson album, it just missed the mark barely. <br /> <br />\\"Bad\\" was released in 1987. Quincy Jones said him and Jackson wanted the next album to have a tougher sound. This involved getting rid of soulful/R and B sound that \\"Off the Wall\\" and \\"Thriller\\" had. This meant less dance-ready songs on the album. Instead, the album would have a more rock and hard sound to it, be more edgy. Also encompassed was syntheziers that sounded very right for the time. People were hungry for the next Jackson album, so many were excited when \\"Bad\\" hit the shelves. <br /> <br />By just looking at the album cover, you can tell this is a new style of Michael Jackson. His skin now light and white, he looks completely different from the black man who released the biggest album in 1982. Also, he is wearing a leather style jacket, showing that he isn't someone to mess with. Though that is pretty laughable, the album indeed is the most personal message from Michael Jackson to date. While \\"Off the Wall\\" is pretty much straight up good times and \\"Thriller\\" is a little darker, but still into the good times, \\"Bad\\" is edgy and personal. MJ wrote 9 of the 11 songs, six hit the top ten, with a record five hitting number one, though the total length of all of them together probably equaled the amount of time that the \\"Thriller\\" songs stayed number one or even the \\"Off the Wall\\" songs. <br /> <br />The songs themselves are pretty solid. The title track is a rocking number where Michael declares his new foundation (who's bad?) Originally scheduled as a duet with pop bad boy Prince, Rodgers backed out when the lyrics weren't up to his liking (Michael uses cleaner lyrics than his royal badness wanted). \\"The Way You Make Me Feel\\" is probably my favorite track. It brings me back to the good times Michael that I enjoy. A very well made dance track. \\"Speed Demon\\" is filler all the way, so skip it over. \\"Liberian Girl\\" is a pretty cool sounding song that didn't become as big as it should have. \\"Just Good Friends\\" is cheesy and kind of stupid, more filler, so skip it as well. \\"Another Part of Me\\" is a song from the Captain EO ride at DisneyWorld (that has long been closed). It's kind of juvenile, so it's okay to listen to once in a while. I find \\"Man in the Mirror\\" preachy and insufferable, so I skip it, but some people like the song. \\"Smooth Criminal\\" is my second favorite song on the album, a very rocking number with an awesome beat. \\"Dirty Diana\\" would work with some artists, but it just doesn't with Michael, a little too hard for his style. It feels almost like \\"Beat It\\" II, but definitely darker and harder. \\"I Just Can't Stop Loving You\\" is a well done love duet. It sounds a lot like \\"The Lady in my Life\\" off the \\"Thriller\\" album, which makes me question why this song hit number one and the one from \\"Thriller\\" wasn't even released as a single. \\"Leave Me Alone\\" confirms the new Michael: a paranoid man on the verge of insanity. For that reason, the song is hard for me to listen to.  <br /> <br />I'm a fan of MJ's older albums, so \\"Bad\\" is my third favorite out of the three Qunicy Jones albums. He doesn't seem as happy and enthusiastic on this one as he did before. Also, this album I feel contained a lot more filler than either one of his past two albums, which are pretty much press play and enjoy records. Finally, Jacksons weird grunts and groans become commonplace, and though I like the \\"shamons\\" and the \\"ows\\" like a true fan would, I find them to be a bit much on this album. I feel MJ worked himself too hard on this to top \\"Thriller\\", and fell short, just like every other album in history basically has. I like the fun, soulful/R & B MJ who wants to start the party and pack the club. I feel that completely missing (except for \\"The Way You Make Me Feel\\") on \\"Bad\\". <br /> <br />\\"Bad\\" isn't bad by any means. It is for the most part a well done album. Unlike the other two past records, it hasn't aged quite as well due to the excessive use of late 80's music technology, but it still sounds pretty good to this date. If you're into the old school MJ, the R & B king of the club, then you might be disappointed by the excess rock and pop in \\"Bad\\". Others who like newer MJ will really enjoy this album. It depends on your tastes, but \\"Bad\\" doesn't appeal to as broad of an audience as \\"Thriller\\" or even \\"Off the Wall.\\" It sold 25 million copies, which is a tremendous feat, but nothing compared to the 50 million of \\"Thriller\\". Jackson wanted mainly complete control and a whole new sound after \\"Bad\\", so this would be the last album produced by Quincy Jones. It might not have ended on a bang, but Jones and Jackson set the stage for the next decade of MJ mania with \\"Bad\\".

B000002X2B|5.0|Never heard of \\"Blows against the empire?\\"  Paul Kantner's ambitious concept album opened to mixed reviews in 1970, and it remains an underappreciated gem today. The album's problem is simply a case of bad timing.  At the start of the seventies, the San Francisco counterculture was in trouble: internal divisions were breaking up the youth movement, the political successes of California governor Ronald Reagan and Richard Nixon proved that the New Left was not as powerful as they thought, and musical tastes were drifting away from the \\"flower power\\" rock that had shaped a generation.  The album's central premise, of hippies stealing a starship and leaving earth for an interstellar utopia, would have been a huge hit just a few years earlier, but it rang stale and  bitter to many ears, earning harsh reviews from the likes of Rolling Stone Magazine. Nowadays, with the turmoil of the sixties far behind, this album can be fully appreciated for what it is: a remarkable stew of folk and rock, crafted  through the collective effort of some of Calfornia's top musicians.  CSN fans will appreciate the contributions of David Crosby, and Grateful Dead members Jerry Garcia, Mickey Hart, and Bill Kreutzman all appear.  The liner notes are very insightful, although it would have been helpful to  have complete documentation on all the performers on each track.  All in all, this is psychedelic rock at its best!
B00005JN2X|2.0|This movie looked like it would be one of the good ones this summer: with Tom Cruise and Mark Ruffalo I expected something fun to watch.  This was neither intelligent (the character development was lengthy *and* flimsy, making the talking-head scenes boring) nor exciting (with the exception of a few sequences near the end).  Most of the plot didn't make sense, the writing was generally dull with only a few good moments, and the contortions that Tom Cruise pulled his face into in attempts to look evil were actually laughable.  More ambitious than a regular action film, but not more intelligent, so the mediocrity just becomes more noticeable.
B000068FUS|5.0|I'm gonna go out on a limb here and call \\"Southern Rock Opera\\" the greatest rock opera of all time.  Certainly it is the most successful in accomplishing what it sets out to do.  It never becomes bogged down in the concept of a fictional band called Betamax Guillotine's rise and (tragic) fall - it is so much more.  The first disc (Act I) functions more as an observation on the modern day south and people's misinformed views about it.  And of course, there's a lot of talk about Skynyrd, who the fictional band is meant to represent.  While all this might sound, well, dumb to most of us Yankees up here in the northeast, I know this album opened MY eyes up to the misconceptions that are so common about the south.  Of course it probably helps that I've always had a soft spot for southern rock.  Likewise, people with a strong disposition against Southern rock probably will despise this record.  But they're missing out.   <br /> <br /> <br />I can honestly say I've never listened to an album like this.  And I've listened to a lot of albums.  It's part sermon, part storytelling, part history, part soul.  Patterson Hood writes and sings most of the songs here, and once again his songs are characterized by his rednecky yet intelligent lyrics and his sublime smoke ravaged voice.  Mike Cooley also contributes some fine songs, especially \\"Zip City\\" which may very well be my favorite track on the record (does his voice remind anyone else of Jay Farrar?).  DBT went with a 3 guitar lineup this time around (like Skynyrd) and the result is some of the most scorching guitar jams since, well...Freebird!  Even some of the more filler-ish songs (of which there are surprisingly few for a double CD) are rescued by the sheer power of the 3 guitar attack.  By the time Act II gets well underway, the tragedy of Skynyrd finally starts to unfold, and the final track, \\"Angels and Fuselage\\", has to be one of the most effective album closers I have ever heard, detailing the wreckage from a dying man's perspective.  One can almost feel the ghost of RVZ while listening to this track...and that is an unbelievable achievement.   <br /> <br />The Drive By Truckers have created a true modern day masterpiece.  Indeed, the reviews received upon release were all positive, sometimes even glowing.  But still, the real recognition goes to the trendy bands of the moment - but this record defies trends.  Over time its stature will undoubtedly grow, but for now you can experience it - pick this record up and spread the good word (and make sure you catch this band live).   <br />
B0002S94BG|5.0|I must admit, I was waiting a while for this reissue to come out, and ever since the first time I read the press release I've been excited about it. Did it deliver, now that I have it in my hand? <br />Yes. Even though I've scraped my way into owning nearly everything I can (within fiscal limits) that has been put out about Jeff, and the fact that I already had versions of many of these songs did not taint the fact that I was no longer stuck with versions that were in 128 kbps or less with everything above 12khz garbled horribly, but could now listen to Jeff in crystal clear 44100 kbps and enjoy every nuance that the recordings have to offer. Sure, some of the tracks have been included on other releases such as the Grace EPs box, but only three of them, one of which (Lost Highway) is now in better context with its pared-down brethren, were available before, and the chance to own the previously unreleased cuts along with the DVD make the release worth it.  <br />Everyone has made a big to-do about the fact that \\"Forget Her\\" was included on the second disc, but what I think are the real worthwhile cuts on the extra material are the Shudder to Think collaboration (which even though it was done extraneously to the sessions for Grace is still a great song that highlights the ever-floating contextual relevance of Jeff's voice against different stylistic backgrounds), and the unaccompanied covers of Nina Simone's \\"The Other Woman\\" and Bob Dylan's \\"Mama, You've Been on my Mind.\\" If for no other reason, these last two covers are worth their salt because of Jeff's interpretation of the songs, which although they don't deviate very drastically from the originals still breathe with the importance of being songs that are important to Jeff, songs that he decided to do off the cuff because he knew them that well, the kind of songs that we don't see on other releases because they were the type of songs that he played for himself. That's what makes the included solo outtakes worth it--Jeff is playing to hear himself play (painfully though hilariously obvious on \\"Alligator Wine\\"). A studio is a damned intimidating place to be; you are there strictly because you will create something before you walk out of it. So the fact that in the face of this expectation, even though not holding to the main focus, Jeff softly reads through something like the Nina Simone song, makes the recording worth a listen. <br />Simply stated, having all the videos on one DVD is great... Now if only the BBC documentary could be packaged by itself for commercial release... <br />In short, if you like Jeff, this is worth it. For all the controversy surrounding Mary Guibert's handling of his estate, the decisions to license songs to places, etc., this package is definitely worth putting your reservations aside (if you have any) and purchasing. <br />I've never figured out why there seems to be such a collective thirst for Jeff's material; maybe because there is actually a tangible point where his archives are exhausted? Maybe simply due to the fact that he's deceased? Whatever the case may be, I also look for the answers. In every chord change, in every song that he played in multiple guitar tunings, in every melody, there is this surge... and I think that the reason people have invested their time into fully digesting what Buckley had to offer is because his music is driven purely by emotion, and that's what makes it so striking. It is the fact that there is nothing under the surface with his music that draws us to it again and again. There is nothing under the surface because it's all there out in the open, different parts beauty, anger, melancholy, and joy, all there for people to have. He never said that he wanted people to take anything specific from his music, merely whatever they wanted. This release offers you ample opportunity for that. Enjoy it. You'll be glad.

B000274THQ|5.0|Oft-repeated images of East Germans joyfully surging through breaches in The Wall have obscured who was left behind.  In this charming story, we learn not all the DDR's residents resisted socialism.  Nor was reunification an unmodified blessing for all.  A half-century of Western propaganda's view of the East has blinded us to such people as Christiane Kerner.  Abandoned by her husband, who's fled to the West, she \\"marries\\" the socialist state, becoming a dedicated worker.  Seeing her son pummeled by Stasi agents during a demonstration, Christiane suffers a heart attack, lapsing into a coma.  Alexander, as devoted to her as she is to socialism, strives to assist her survival.  The surrounding world strives to defeat him.<br /><br />Honecker's DDR is collapsing around the family leaving Alexander with the task of trying to restore the past.  His mother's survival, when she awakens, depends on his success.  As the \\"man of the family\\" he struggles to keep his sister, her boyfriend, his own new girlfriend and his mother's colleagues on stage in his bizarre scenario.  Food jars are re-labelled, TV news is contrived and the new world of \\"freedom\\" is kept away.  However, the pressure of Coca Cola and Burger King is strong - and Alexander must cope with them all.<br /><br />Ironies abound in this stunning presentation of \\"the other side\\".  Alexander describes the DDR military as \\"the world's last great shooting club\\".  A demonstration becomes people \\"getting together for a little exercise\\".  Christiane's dedication, which has nothing to do with politics or philosophy, is intense, but not absolute.  She hungers for what she already has, but remains unfulfilled.  Socialism isn't perfect - she streams complaint letters to the authorities.  Her \\"marriage\\" to the ideal is reminiscent of Christian nuns.  Will she die \\"in the Faith\\" as so many others have done?  Becker uses this and other images masterfully.  The red banners of the DDR merge deftly those of Coca Cola, Germany's most recent invader.<br /><br />Becker's imagery and dialogue presentation is vivid and subtle at once.  He uses his characters brilliantly - Hitchcock would approve, even if there's no mystery to unveil.  With a contrasting mix of slow and fast action, Becker depicts the upheavals surrounding the collapse of German socialism with stunning clarity.  As the Special Features reveal, this film was cut by a third and the missing scenes are tantalising.  An film worthy of all its awards and attention.  Watch it and see \\"the other side\\" as it was.  [stephen a. haines - Ottawa, Canada]s most recent invader.   <br /> <br />Becker's imagery and dialogue presentation is vivid and subtle at once. 0393035158|4.0|It's about time someone wrote forcefully about the very unpopular reality of what religion has done through time-- and continues to do-- in justifying evil and retarding our development as a species.     Harris tackles some very complex theories about beliefs, reason and faith, in a way that even the average reader can grasp. While his comments are harsh when necessary -and will probably offend the faithful-his thesis is not without merit.     Since humans are resistant to having their core beliefs challenged (even successfully) this may be a hard read for some. But it is a necessary read if we are to have any hope of preserving our species. If we keep heading down the path we're on, our destruction is a near certainty.    This is not to say that this book is thoroughly depressing. Rather, Harris offers some paradigm shifts which must occur if there is to be any hope of finding humans on earth at the dawn of the next millennia.     I challenge any believer to take on the incontrovertible facts Harris puts forth, and to `argue' them with sound reasoning, not blind faith in unprovable concepts. This would be impossible.     I was most surprised that a book on this subject turned out to be a real page-turner I could not put down. For anyone with an open mind, I highly recommend it.
B00005JL78|5.0|Brace yourself - intelligent sci-fi isn't dead, nor is it an oxymoron. You wouldn't have known that for several years, with dull releases such as Alien:Resurrection, Battlefield Earth, the new Star Wars travesties, Chronicles of Riddick, and Starship Troopers littering the sci-fi landscape with one dreadful bomb after another. Minority Report breaks that chain, and shows Steven Speilberg in top form once again. <br /> <br />Of course it's Spielberg - who else is out there to bring 5 start science-fiction to the screen? This is the man that brought us E.T. over 20 years ago, also regarded as one of the greatest sci-fi movies in history. When he chooses to, Spielberg delivers movies with carefully crafted stories, fully developed characters that draw us in and that we care about, realistic scripts, and of course special-effects that support the film rather than stand center-stage as the main focus. This film is not only no exception, it raises Spielberg's bar. <br /> <br />Tom Cruise is well cast in his role as the cop at the center of the film, but the supporting cast is where the excellence truly lies. Max Von Sydow plays his role to perfection and never lets you really know, until the end, where his loyalties lie. Colin Farrell, playing Cruise's foil, is more than just Hollywood's new pretty boy here - this film gives him real meat to work with and act with. And he's really good at it. <br /> <br />This film exemplifies what science fiction film should be. Beyond eye-candy with too many special effect, sci-fi should be a reflection of our present condition and present day life, and should provoke us to think about ourselves, or our society, or our condition. This film does so and lends itself to multiple viewings, each time giving us something new to see or think about. <br /> <br />I cannot recommend this film too many times. Easily one of the ten best science fiction films in history.

B00005B36H|5.0|Let me start this review by stating that this is one of the best albums I have every heard.  By any standard, it is a masterpiece, but in the genre of 'Progressive Rock,' whatever the hell that is, it is quite possibly the best album ever produced.  The scope of this album is immense - long sequences of sedate, droning sounds, marked by explosions of energy that will stay with you long after you've put the album away.  The transitions between the two extremes are where the real magic happens.  This album is smart and aggressive, but to me completely accessible, because not a note is wasted.  Every drumbeat, every lyric, every chord has behind it the purpose of a greater vision, and in that, Tool has proven itself to be one of the most important bands currently making music.

B000002HEP|5.0|Kyuss's third album, Welcome to Sky Valley, is difficult to discribe in human language. To that end, it is impossible to believe that mortal men are responsible for creating what is quite possibly the greatest album in recorded history.     While Blues for the Red Sun was easily one of the best records no one has ever heard, Welcome to Sky Valley is the best record that man will never appreciate simply because he is not able to.  On the surface, this album seems to promise the same premise as its predecessor: Thundering Riffs, amazing rhythms, stark desert poetry, and classic tracks. Make no mistake, Welcome to Sky Valley has all that and more.     The opening track, Gardenia, has to be the one of the greatest intro songs ever recorded by human beings. The massive riff was like nothing ever done. Each song flows into the next almost seamlessly, which makes you understand  that this album is not a collection of songs, but a single cohesive piece of music.  There is not one weak piece of music on this one. It seems to be more diverse than Kyuss's previous efforts. The thundering Gardenia, the relaxed Space Cadet and the drug like Asteroid make this one a varied piece of desert rock.     The last time i listened to this one( which was like 15 min prior to me writing this), I swore I was in Barstow, California, with the high heat and Joshua  Trees reminding me of simpler time when music was not just a product, but an energetic release of emotion, chaos and beauty. Buy this one at all costs.     It is not necessarily a requirement for rock fans, but for all humans to listen to and see that people are capapble of creating some of the startling pieces of art. Put the disc in, let in spin and soon you will be at peace...
0393035158|4.0|It is both odd and a mistake to refer to this book as \\"ineffectual\\". Mr. Harris points out something which, one hopes, we all already know. And that is, despite its ability to blind us emotionally, despite the fact that in most cases people come to embrace religion through some form of indoctrination, or in the case of President Bush, come to it as a substitute for other forms of intoxication, religion as an artifact of human thought has long outlived its usefulness. We are no longer tribes squatting in huts teaching our children that the world is flat and if the weather turns it's because some god is angry about the clothes we wear. Problem being that today, in place of sticks and rocks we have big, powerful and easily portable weapons.<br /><br />What is effective about this book is that it finally opens the door to this virtually taboo observation: Middle east or West, by being treated as infallible and unquestionable, religion quantifiably does more harm than good. Mr. Harris points out just how utterly antiquated and basically wrong so many religious tracts are by using the tracts themselves. Proof enough that religions no longer hold the key to human happiness is demonstrated by the convenient \\"editing\\" of some tenets of faith by none other than the faithful who, in our culture, get closer to god by picking and choosing those aspects of the word of god which best suits the starkly more secular and practical aspects of their lives. Is everybody comfy? Good.<br /><br />It is even more important and highly effective to point out how faith continues to divert our society from coming to terms with the objective facts which define the issues facing us today in favor of consistently relying on belief. The dangers of this practice in our daily social and political life are being felt in innumerable ways, and the danger continues to grow. By connecting the way in which religious beliefs affect our world, our interaction with others and with a more objective reality, Mr. Harris has helped begin the only conversation that really matters.ped begin the only conversation that really matters.

The only one that isn't is No Quarter, which is one of the band's finest compositions. As a whole, Houses of the Holy is great rock music, one that deserves to be in any Zeppelin fan's collection. It may seem like haphazardly through together music, but that is the point. Led Zeppelin made a fun record and made it well. You should definitely check this one out.

078322608X|5.0|This is perhaps the most misunderstood romantic movie of all times. <br /> <br />Or maybe mine is just a very particular interpretation of it. <br /> <br />Like _Brazil_, another masterpiece, _12 Monkeys_ deals with an ill-starred love affair in a setting so dense with ideas it is very difficult to see the tree in such a forest. The themes touched are many: ecology and ecoterrorism; viruses and apocalypse; the Cassandra complex; time travel; madness and awareness; consumerism; etc. But in this forest of themes, sometimes so dense as to be mind boggling, the central element is what two people feel for each other. <br /> <br />We're hinted at the nature of the central theme by recurring bits along the movie: the dream, the persecution scenes (Cole and Dr. Railly spend their time together on the run), the way they both become aware of each other, the spy who finally tells Cole he wants her, and above all the scene in the movie theatre where _Vertigo_ is playing. <br /> <br />_Vertigo_, a Hitchcock masterpiece, also deals with an ill-starred romance and, just like _Brazil_ and _12 Monkeys_, the reasons why it can't be are unsurmountable: in _Vertigo_, Johnny-O falls for a woman who has taken the personality of another woman already dead, so the love-object does not really exist; in _Brazil_, the omnipotent state is between Sam and Jill; in _12 Monkeys_, the inetability of destiny is interposed between James and Kathryn. <br /> <br />Also, like in _Vertigo_, both characters develop true romance while going in the car. The acting by Willis when he listens to music for perhaps the first time, when he breathes in the air without germs, when he sees the beautiful skies and shining light of day, is, in my opinion, superb. All these things we take for granted, just like love, are denied to this social outcast in that moribund future. <br /> <br />The scene outside the movie theater had me in tears. Here they are, kissing for the first and last time, and he looks at Kathryn andsays: \\"in my dream... it was you... always.\\" <br /> <br />Dystopias usually exist to warn people of the dangers in the present and how they might affect the future. \\"1984\\" and \\"Brave New World\\" are typical examples. Books tend to focus on the more brainy side of it, but in the end it is the individual who matters. And nothing is more proper to the free person than her or his feelings. <br /> <br />The dystopic vision in _Brazil_ or _12 Monkeys_ is senseless. A giant apparatus that exists for no purpose, except perhaps to make the lives of most people empty but acceptable. Love breaks that: it is the ultimate meaning-giver. That such love is impossible gives the people taking part in it the character of heroes in a greek tragedy--they know nothing can be done, they know what they're doing is foolish, but they do it the same because it is who they are in their most intimate recesses of their soul. <br /> <br />James Cole is given a final choice: he kills or Kathryn is killed. He's not told who he's supposed to shoot, but we can infer it is himself. His duty is to die, so he can be a hero. So he runs to meet destiny, and we're left with the pieces of a circular time where these two people are condemned to meeting again and again, always towards the same despairing, inevitable end. <br /> <br />This is a very dense movie open to many interpretations. As usual, Gilliam is insightful, smart, and does not say everything in order to make you think your alternate and very personal version. The DVD is very good, with an excellent documentary (\\"The Hamster Effect\\") that touches on topics that won't be unfamiliar to many of us. The acting is first rate, with Brad Pitt giving an amazing performance, similarly for Willis and Stowe. <br /> <br />_12 Monkeys_ is a demanding, literate movie that will be better appreciated by those who love a good dose of thought in their books and movies.
B000089RV6|5.0|Mutt Lang + Malcom Young = ROCK!!!!!!!! <br />WHY DON'T YOU ALREADY HAVE THIS ALBUM? BUY IT NOW YOU MORON!

0393035158|3.0|I enjoyed the book but am waiting for more scientific or psychological research that will give us more insight into why people are compelled to blind religious faith.  <br /> <br />The author focuses on the phenomenon that religious people have throughout history committed violent crimes.  <br /> <br />It's easy to see why this might happen: Most people are sinners. The sinner fights mightily to keep up the walls that prevent him from seeing his dark side clearly. When a sinner realizes there's a way out by believing in God, he allows such suppressed knowledge to flood his consciousness. At the same moment, his sins are now completely forgiven. Sometimes what has to be admitted is that the world is a scary place full of sinners. It's easier to accept if - at the same moment - the individual believes that he is on God's side and that God will personally protect him. <br /> <br />So people often find religion because they are loathe to admit such things all by themselves. But under God's protection, once they admit of their selves as sinners, they can then - during that same instantaneous break - feel good because now they don't have to worry about eternal damnation. And now that God loves them, they can do all those bad things again and not feel guilty about it. Hence, once individuals of a certain personality type are converted, they would rather kill then once again feel guilt, fear of the world, or fear of eternal damnation.  <br /> <br />Ironic, isn't it.

0345457684|4.0|Richard K. Morgan's first published novel is an effective blend of hardboiled detective story and cyberpunk. Takeshi Kovacs is a highly trained ex-special operations soldier (aka Envoy) whose body has been killed, his personality digitally stored \\"on stack\\" for crimes on his home world. When a very wealthy and influential man on Earth dies, he buys the convict's personality, has it downloaded to a body on good ol' terra firma, and sets Kovacs to the task of solving his death: was it suicide or murder? <br /> <br />While this is overall a well-written novel, there are also several of those moments that make you want scream, \\"What was he THINKING?\\" For instance, twice in the course of the story, Morgan has characters, one Kovacs, the other a veteran cop, drawing their guns - auto pistols - and dramatically racking the slides to chamber rounds before going into action, or while actually being attacked. Speaking as a 2002 state combat pistol champion who's been making his living evaluating and writing about guns for the past 12 years, let make this really simple for you: no one with two brain cells to rub together carries an auto pistol without a round already in the chamber. Certainly not an experienced special ops soldier or a tough-as-nails police detective. A minor bit of research on guns here would have prevented Morgan making this rookie mistake. <br /> <br />Then he has Kovacs, post-firefight, reloading his gun by popping out the partially spent magazine, then laboriously fishing a spare out of his jacket pocket (of COURSE he didn't carry it easily accessible in a spare magazine pouch, those highly trained killers always have their spare ammo rattling about in the bottom of a pocket, natch), inserting the fresh magazine into the gun, then racking the slide to chamber a cartridge. Uh, no. After you're fired an auto pistol and you've still got a half-loaded mag in the gun, there's ALREADY a round in the chamber. Jeez. Obviously Morgan knows very little about guns but thinks it's really bitchin' and macho to show a character racking an auto pistol's slide. I mean, that's how you know someone's SERIOUS. Right? <br /> <br />Also, I must admit I found it a bit irritating the way Morgan, time after time throughout the book, referred to the detachable box that holds ammunition and inserts into an auto pistol's butt as a \\"magazine\\" in one sentence, and a \\"clip\\" in the very next. These are not synonyms. In some guns we do have what are called \\"clips.\\" A clip is a non-mechanical device, i.e. it has no moving parts, it's just a piece of metal, designed to hold cartridges for storage, or so they can go into a magazine. A magazine is a mechanical device, it has moving parts, designed to hold cartridges so they can go into a firing chamber. Imagine you were a computer programmer, and how jarring you'd find it if a writer continually referred to a RAM as a ROM. I mean, who cares, they're almost the same thing. Right? <br /> <br />Then we have the scene where Kovacs is standing on the street, over the body of a friend who's just been tossed from a car. The verbiage goes, \\"...I lowered myself into a crouch beside Ortega and reached down to her face....warm breath stirred around my fingertips. I felt blindly toward the neck for a pulse and found it, weak but stable.\\" <br /> <br />Why is it the two things most writers get wrong are always guns and first aid? Speaking as a graduate of the EMT course, here's a basic fact for you: as soon as the heart stops beating, a person immediately stops breathing. If a person is breathing, de facto their heart is beating, there's no need to check for a pulse. This is basic first aid. A highly trained, combat experienced spec ops veteran like Kovacs would know that. <br /> <br />Then Kovacs tells Ortega to bug out, and gets in the car so the bad guy, an assassin who's sworn Kovacs' death, can kidnap him to his probable demise. WHY? To protect Ortega? Please. Kovacs had Mr. Bad Guy covered with his gun, he had the upper hand. True, there were two muscleheads in the car, as well, but (a) he didn't know that yet, (b) he'd already demonstrated numerous times throughout the book he could handle such pug uglies without breaking a sweat. So why get in the car? Why risk his life? Why not just shoot the bad guy, deal with the inconsequentialities in the car, then trip merrily on his way? Well, obviously because Morgan wanted to get Kovacs into the death trap to come. The deus ex machina was in full view at this point, the wires moving the character like a puppet not even hidden. <br /> <br />Don't get me wrong, I enjoyed this novel. But I would have enjoyed it more with the addition of some basic research on Morgan's part about firearms and first aid, and a bit less artificiality moving the plot forward at times.
B0001ZMWQO|2.0|These guys are relatively proficient at sounding like a cheap rip-off of XTC circa 1981, but how does this equal the next big thing? B0000028UK|5.0|I always find it hard for some reason to review albums I love. Well, since Pearl Jam's \\"Vs.\\" is my second-favorite album of all time (my favorite being Nirvana's \\"In Utero\\") this is incredibly difficult. What can I say beyond I love this album and you should too? I'm going to try my best, though. <br /> <br />This album is so great because it touches on everything, at least every emotion. There's angry songs (\\"Leash,\\" \\"Blood\\") introspective songs (\\"Elderly Woman Behind the Counter In A Small Town,\\" \\"Indifference\\") desperate songs (\\"Rearviewmirror,\\" \\"Dissident\\") and social commentary songs (\\"W.M.A.,\\" \\"Glorified G\\"). No matter what kind of mood you're in, there's a song here for you. Even if you're happy and you just want to blast something, this album is perfect, especially with the opening punch of \\"Go\\" and \\"Animal.\\" <br /> <br />The musicianship on this album, as can be expected with Pearl Jam, is phenomenal. Mike McCready begins to really emerge as one of the most talented guitar players of his generation, and he is perfectly balanced by Stone Gossard. Dave Abruzzesse is great as well, and he really gets a chance to shine on the pounding conclusion of \\"Rearviewmirror.\\" Jeff Ament's bass always seems to underscore the music brilliantly. And of course, Eddie Vedder's vocals are top-notch. It's amazing that he could scream out songs like \\"Blood\\" and \\"Leash\\" night after night without losing his voice completely.  <br /> <br />Eddie also begins to develop as a lyricist here -- there's a radical difference between the relatively straightforward lyrics of \\"Alive\\" and the poignancy of songs like \\"Daughter\\" and \\"Elderly Woman . . .\\" There's also a cool lyrical (and musical) experiment in \\"Rats,\\" which compares the human race to the rat race, with the conclusion that the humans aren't much better than the rodents. <br /> <br />\\"Vs.\\" is a beautiful, cathartic, emotional album. It is angry, yes -- but there are several soft spots as well, with the band beginning to show theirdiversity. They made the best move possible by not coming out with another \\"Ten,\\" a move that would set the tone for the rest of their interesting career. Pearl Jam has not sold out to date, and they continue to make great records that they want to make, never pandering to critics. \\"Vs.\\" is the greatest record, and you would be well-advised to pick it up and experience it.

B000059T00|5.0|This is one of those classics that is well known and populat but never said in the same breath as disraeli gears or the band.  it should be. the album is a clear stepping stone between cream and clapton's later project derek and the dominos.   <br /> <br />can't find my way home is an elegantly understated majestic and pastoral song with steve winwood's most rousing and angelic vocals. had to cry today and sea of joy are two wonderful rock songs, which add fire to the rock riff (already rather dated by 1969) and do what you like has a great jam with two of the best solos heard by clapton or winwood on record - very psychedelic.  presence of the lord has a great clapton vocal (i belive his first great vocal) and a brilliant hendrix inspired solo. sea of joy has great violin breaks by rick grech and well alright is a winwood vehicle - great piano solo but the weakest on the album. <br /> <br />all in all a very good album. oh and did i forget to mention - ginger baker's drumming is incredible throughout - great timekeeping and imaginative fills all over the place.  <br /> <br />shame about the new cover but then, to be honest, the old one wasn't really that great was it? - and a bit odd considering all.    i would urge you to get the vinyl original though - for some reason nearly all early clapton stuff (till mid-70s) is not as good on cd.  especially cream - which loses the great rhythm tracks on stereo and more or less all their original verve on cd. <br /> <br />give it a whirl along with wheels of fire and layla for a full-on clapton experience from this era

B0000DJZA5|5.0|LET IT BE has generated more controversey than any other Beatles album. What many people expected this to be was GET BACK, the original name for the album and accompanying film, which was deliberately loose and un-organized (as the sessions actually were; listen to the \\"Fly on the Wall\\" disc for more info on that). This is NOT GET BACK. This is a professional product, with all the rough part smoothed out. In some ways, it suffers in comparison to the original album (\\"Get Back\\" has no improv at the end, and Lennon's remarks are eliminated from the album altogether.) Still, the arrangements have benefitted the album. <br /> <br />\\"Let It Be\\" sounds much more interesting, taking away Spector's echo effects on the cymbals and the repeated verse at the end. \\"Across The Universe\\" is much more beautiful the second time around, with the track sped up and the choirs gone, leaving a subtle, acoustic performance from Lennon. \\"The Long and Winding Road\\" is also a marked improvement, this time with none of the pompous orchestrations that made it sappy. While I have my gripes about it (I think the guitar in the song is a bit unnecessary), it is still better than the original. <br /> <br />The other tracks have been left alone, although there is a professional sound to it that the original lacked. While that may make it bad for some, I'd keep in mind that the Beatles' true last album, ABBEY ROAD, sounds just as cared for and meticuously produced, and it is a masterpiece. <br /> <br />All in all, I'd say that this is worth the money, and it is a definite improvement on the original.
B0001UL7RY|1.0|In 1995 an album titled Jagged Little Pill under Madonna's then-new fledgling label, Maverick Records, managed to make pop history. A collection of raw rock ditties put together by a little-know artist by the name of Alanis Morrisette broke records and launched a platform for every female artist. Not coincidentally the Lilith Fair era was on the rise back then, because music audiences started paying attention to female singer songwriters from a folk / rock category, which was predominantly testosterone-filled arena.<br /><br />Almost a decade later, this phenomenon has faded, not because of lack of material or emerging artists, but because of an underlying sexist factor. It's not easy to have a strong woman signed to a label. Sinead O'Conner, anyone?<br /><br />Artists such as Joan Osborne and Alana Davis have been dropped from their label. Natalie Merchant and Tracy Chapman have both been mistreated by their companies. Both Fiona Apple and Sarah McLachlan took an immensely long hiatus. And the rise of Rap and Hip Hop left everybody wondering what the next big things is.<br /><br />Of course, in true music biz fashion, the moguls created more package-ready and compact pretty versions of what was earthy and not so manufactured artists.<br /><br />This spans everyone from the awfully bland Michelle Branch to the more recent tragedy FeFe Dobson. However, the most successfully one of that bunch has to be faux-punk Avril Lavigne - The bigwig's way of cashing into teenage rebellion by avoiding the pretty counter-Britney.<br /><br />Let Go, her first album, annoyed everyone with the drag-along \\"Complicated\\" only partially rising with \\"Sk8er Boi\\" and then \\"Losing Grip.\\" Offering boring balladry in \\"I'm With You\\" along the way. With those songs she tapped into the heart of every girl and boy who are furious for not wanting to do their homework, thus collecting money and some ill-conceived recognition from critics.<br /><br />Under My Skin is the second round for this wide-eyed little Barbie punk. The album's glossy booklet demonstrates her undying effort at making herself look tough. Avril already scored a hit the mundane \\"Don't Tell Me\\" and now gaining swift success with the slightly brighter \\"My Happy Ending.\\" Other than the video magic, Avril sifts through this hapless release with a great mush of rock songs that are destined to temporarily spark a kid's interest and then disappear as a funny period of pop culture, kind of like the powers rangers. There is no difference between, say, \\"Fall To Pieces,\\" \\"Take Me Away\\" and the closing track \\"Slipped Away.\\"<br /><br />\\"Nobody's Home\\" and \\"Forgotten\\" are apt for Avril fans - both songs of bubblegum anguish.<br /><br />This is not to say that Lavigne won't be a favorite with MTV still and have a growing catalogue of hits, but she has yet to prove that she is an individual artist with a profound talent other than the physical and musical tweaking of industry masterminds.<br /><br />If Sid Vicious knew that punk would come to this, he wouldn't have bothered.e album's glossy booklet demonstrates her undying effort at making herself look tough. B0000027RL|5.0|`Ten' is, quite simply put, the finest and most complete album EVER. <br /> <br />Ok, let's start with the inevitable comparisons.  Nirvana?  Where are they now?  Admittedly Dave Grohl is an absolute genius and a legend (mainly from his `after nirvana' projects though) but Nirvana was Kurt Cobain!!  How can you compare lyrics like `what else can I say, everyone is gay' to `my bitter hands cradle broken glass of what was everything'?  You can't!  Eddie Vedder is a poet, a lyrical genius.  Ok, they had long hair, they had guitarists and drummers - so are Nirvana therefore comparable to Avril Lavigne?  Then we have the Seattle thing - `The Corrs' (or `The Bores') hail from the same land as the illustrious `Thin Lizzy' (pioneers of rock) - do I hear comparisons?  I rest my case. <br /> <br />Now that we've got that over with let's get back to `Ten'. <br /> <br />Most of the previous comments refer to the indisputable musical quality of the album but the qualities that stand out for me are the lyrics and the raw emotions that we hear from Vedder in every song.  It's like every song is based on a deep personal experience of his, not just words that have to be sung as with the majority of bands over the past 20 years.  I first bought this album on cassette back in '92 when I was 12, then updated to CD a few years later which wore out after a couple of years so I had to buy it again.  My collection is empty without this one.  It's like an addiction - I need my fix every couple of months!  This is the one album that has stood the test of time for me and I don't envisage ever tiring of it.  Every time I take it out it seems to get better and better for me and, while the first half was my favourite for a few years, each half seem to take turns at being my favourite.   <br /> <br />`Alive' started out being a personal experience of Eddies and sharply became the first of the `Mamason' trilogy - in my opinion `once' being the best.  I just love the simple but haunting appendage of `you think I got my eyes closed but I'm looking at you the whole f**king time'.  `Even flow' represents the swift demise of a homeless man into insanity.  `Why go' - Grunge?  Come on!!!  I see bands trying to emulate this every week on Kerrang but with no success.  `Black' is possibly the most moving song ever written.  Lie in bed, turn off the light, turn up the volume and let it take you away - I dare you to tell me you're not moved.  Every line strikes a chord with anyone who's ever experienced loss and it's impossible not to feel his pain when he sings lines like `tattooed all I see, all that I am, all I'll ever be...'.  He captures the seemingly endless feeling of emptiness when love is lost.  Of the second half, I think `deep' is my favourite.  In my opinion it's probably the most underrated song on the album - maybe people have difficulties getting past the first excellent half of the CD, falsely believing that the second half couldn't possibly be as remarkable.  `Deep' tackles the three difficult issues of drug addiction, suicide and rape (in my interpretation) and the mindset of the people who do such things.  In the third verse especially, Vedder captures the mood perfectly; `she doesn't like the view... but he sinks himself deep'. <br /> <br />`Ten' still manages to blow me away every time.  For those of you who wish to make such obtuse comments as to compare Pearl Jam to minor players like `Creed', `StainD', `Puddle of Mud', etc; that's ok, I know you don't know any better but I'm sure you'll learn.  Let's see where those other artists will be in ten, twenty years!  `Ten' has already been hailed as a masterpiece by most of those in the know.  I don't really care for critics but in this case they're spot on - `Ten' will still be sitting in or beside my CD player in 20 years and that's the best accolade I can bestow it. <br />

What's more, she's now got a son, John (Josh Hartnett) to go along with her life!  After an old counselor of Strode's is killed, Michael discovers that his sister isn't dead and exactly where she lives.  On the weekend that Michael arrives, the school Laurie works for is on a class trip and the only remaining people are her, John, and some of his friends and staff which makes a classic setting for a refresher in becoming the scared babysitter all over again!  When Laurie first comes face to face with Michael she almost thinks it's her mind playing tricks on her, but it quickly becomes much more real and horrifying from the moment she finds that he is no delusion! <br /> <br />This movie re-vamped the \\"formula\\" to making a successful slasher film and even brought back some aspects of a successful Halloween film and the result was incredible.  The storyline is tight, no holes, and simple, which keeps it very close to the original.  The use of music and shadows also bring back a sense of boogeyman in Michael and having the hole campus empty gave plenty of room to be realistic!  The body count is quite low, but again that's what made this movie better!  Jamie Lee Curtis comes back after 20 years and proves that she's still got what it takes to be crowned the \\"scream queen\\" of horror.  Additional cast members also help bring this movie to life with modern idols like Josh Hartnett, Michelle Williams, and my personal favorite: L.L. Cool J!  This movie took what they'd done in the past, updated it, and made a sequel that is worthy of being compared to the original. <br /> <br />The DVD is a decent collector's edition, but we've been spoiled in the past by films that we knew little about, and unfortunately H20 got plenty of press coverage.  It's got a fun featurette, but nothing that compares to the behind the scenes work for the original or parts 4 & 5.  The movie itself is presented in widescreen with surround sound which preserves that cold chill I felt in the theatre when I went to see it (and I'm not talking about the air conditioning)!  Fans of the series don't need to be told at this point to pick this up and horror fans can honestly get away with this and the original for your collection.  All around movie fans may want to rent first as this is still a \\"slasher\\" film.

B000002KET|3.0|So says the Master of Sabbath, Tony Iommi, regarding \\"Sabbath Bloody Sabbath.\\"  Of course, he's right.  It's very experimental and not really heavy metal. <br /> <br />For years I wouldn't even buy it because of the cover because I don't dig all the pseudo-Satanic dreck.  I also don't like the title of the painting, \\"The Rape Of Christ.\\"  However, when taken in context with the back cover, it makes a little more sense, especially given that \\"The Exorcist\\" was so big at the time.  One star off for the cover, though. <br /> <br />This album is regarded by many as \\"Sabbath's finest hour\\" (of course, many say that about any Sabbath album Ozzy \\"sang\\" on).  I wouldn't say that, but I would say that it's a cross between brave experimentation and drug-addled aimlessness (this album contains some of Geezer's most impenetrable lyrics).  The production (by Tony Iommi, credited to the band) is good and some of the songs are good, some less so, and the playing by the three instrumentalists (abetted by Yes keyboardist Rick Wakeman, though on what tracks I don't know) is good. <br /> <br />\\"Sabbath Bloody Sabbath\\" - This is the most typical heavy Sabbath song on the album and the strongest cut.  Quite heavy, though Iommi throws in some nice acoustic interludes.  Excellent guitar solo.  Ozzy in this day and age is unable to \\"sing\\" the high-register final verses and the current Sharon Osbourne Hits, Ltd., version of Sabbath restricts these verses to an instrumental.  To hear them sung really well, check out Tony Martin's rendition on \\"Cross Purposes Live\\". <br /> <br />\\"A National Acrobat\\" - Well constructed, less heavy than the title cut.  Incomprehensible lyrics. <br /> <br />\\"Fluff\\" - Exactly what it says!  Acoustic fluff!  Tony plays all the instruments here.  I can discern acoustic guitar, classical guitar, cleanly-played electric guitar, steel guitar and piano.  As has been noted, kind of has a \\"music box\\" flavour.  The band used a recording of this as their live \\"outro\\" during the Ronnie James Dio years. <br /> <br />\\"Sabbra Cadabra\\" - Clever title, Geezer, but doesn't fit the song.  Almost poppy, with Ozzy singing about his current lady love.  Wakeman's (?) keyboards are quite prominent. <br /> <br />\\"Killing Yourself To Live\\" - The most straightforward track on the disc besides the title track.  Basic rock but not quite heavy metal.  Lyrically recounts Sabbath's troubles with the music business.  Obligatory drug promotion as Ozzy wheezes \\"Smoke it...Get High!\\" <br /> <br />\\"Who Are You?\\" - Other than \\"The Wizard,\\" the only known instance of Ozzy \\"playing\\" an instrument (he does the one-fingered synthesiser melody).  Very strange song with Ozzy hurling invective at a deity - not sure if it's God or Satan.  Good orchestral-type ending though. <br /> <br />\\"Looking For Today\\" - Again, almost poppy.  I think this is the only time I've heard handclaps on a Sabbath song!  Well-written and structured (Bill Ward's percussion is outstanding) but again not very heavy. <br /> <br />\\"Spiral Architect\\" - \\"Epic\\" type of song that gets a bit too grandiose at times.  I think this is supposed to be about God deciding who is created and who isn't...again, must be the drugs talking.  Overdubbed audience applause toward the end. <br /> <br />The band are to be commended for experimentation but really they went too far with it on this album and would continue to do so for the remainder of the Ozzy era, remaining more than a bit directionless (costing another star) until the Dio-powered comeback in 1980. <br /> <br />The cover alone is probably responsible for much of the goofy satanic stuff inflicted by the likes of Mercyful Fate/King Diamond, Venom et al in the ensuing years. <br /> <br />Not a bad album, but certainly not as great as some make it out to be.  Of course, it sells by the tankload just because Ozzy is on it.

B0002DB52M|5.0|DOGVILLE is unlike almost any film you will see.  Writer Director Lars von Trier once again has dared to pry open the truths concealed by conventional facades to examine the human condition, the plight of human survival in a world populated by intimidated individuals who only define their public identity by affiliating/identifying with the Norm.  In so many ways this story with a Prologue and Nine Chapters is a morality play ad as such it is piercingly poignant and superbly constructed.  This film is a minimalist film: the 'sets' are diagrammed lines on the floor, the props are spare, the action all taking lace on a sound stage that appears like a Joseph Cornell box.<br /><br />The Depression Years in America, a time of gangsters, poverty and minimal communication of world events to the tiny towns on the Midwest. Dogville is a rural small town in the Midwest peopled by what appear to be good folk.  Into this scene enters a beautiful girl on the run Grace (a luminous Nicole Kidman) who seems to be in flight from gangsters.  The town's philosopher Tom (Paul Bettany in an extraordinary performance) finds Grace, hides her in the town's mineshaft (over the door is the inscription 'Speak the Truth'...), and convinces the townsfolk to harbor her.  In exchange for this kindness Grace must do some work for each of them everyday as a gesture of good will.  When the police come looking for Grace later, the townsfolk still protect her but the price is doubling the amount of work she must do in reparation. Slowly this town of kind appearing folk become wary of Grace, start lies about her, abuse her sexually and physically, and eventually fetter her as their prisoner. Tom advises her to address the townsfolk with the whole truth of how the individuals in the town, quite apart form acting as a group,  have been secretly treating her: the truth will make you free sort of confession.  From that point the story turns and the ending is so very powerful that even hinting at the last chapter would rob the audience of the incredible impact.<br /><br />von Trier has gathered a cast of brilliant actors: in addition to Nicole Kidman and Paul Bettany, the cast includes Patricia Clarkson, Lauren Bacall, Ben Gazzara, Stellan Skarsgard, Chloe Sevigny, Harriet Andersson, James Caan, Phil Baker Hall, Jeremy Davies, and the eloquent off stage narrator John Hurt.  Despite the length of the film (close to three hours) the tension never lapses.  The only true criticism of the film is some very unnecessarily choppy editing.  The musical score is haunting and the final credits (von Trier tastefully opens his film with no credits at all) are presented with many of the photographs of Dorothea Lange from her Depression Series, and photographs by other artists who show the effects of poverty throughout the world.  It leaves you breathless.  This film is a triumph, it calls for your involvement as a viewer, and it has lessons about morality and the individual's plight in an angry world. Highly Recommended.chapter would rob the audience of the incredible impact. <br /> <br />von Trier has gathered a cast of brilliant actors: in addition to Nicole Kidman and Paul Bettany, the cast includes Patricia Clarkson, Lauren Bacall, Ben Gazzara, Stellan Skarsgard, Chloe Sevigny, Harriet Andersson, James Caan, Phil Baker Hall, Jeremy Davies, and the eloquent off stage narrator John Hurt.  Despite the length of the film (close to three hours) the tension never lapses.  The only true criticism of the film is some very unnecessarily choppy editing.  The musical score is haunting and the final credits (von Trier tastefully opens his film with no credits at all) are presented with many of the photographs of Dorothea Lange from her Depression Series, and photographs by other artists who show the effects of poverty throughout the world.  It leaves you breathless.  This film is a triumph, it calls for your involvement as a viewer, and it has lessons about morality and the individual's plight in an angry world. Highly Recommended.

B00026W82U|4.0|This band takes time to write well crafted, sedate, meditative songs, synthesizing such influences as Simon and Garfunkel, Prefab Sprout, and Astrud Gilberto. With a whispering, plaintive voice, the vocalist breathes lightly over mostly acoustic guitar arrangements with easy-listing bossa nova beat. The result is a second album that's easy to listen to, very atmospheric, and very thoughtful. So why only four stars? Like the first album, this one doesn't get much play because there's a sameness and a monotony to the songs. Still, if you want to bliss out for an hour, it's hard to do better. If you like blissing out to slow, melancholy songs, you might also check out Just for a Day by Slowdive and the albums of Mojave 3.
0312263120|2.0|Compared to his other three books that I have read (Deception Point, The DaVinci Code, and Angels & Demons), this book falls short of my expectations.<br /><br />The main character of this book, Susan Fletcher, is introduced as an exceedingly intelligent, technically brilliant cryptographer who is called in to her work at the NSA to investigate a cipher that the NSA has been unable to break.<br /><br />While the description of what the environment behind the closed doors at the NSA might be like was interesting, the discussion about the science of cryptography itself was a bit disappointing. One of the key reasons that breaking encryption is hard is that, for certain types of problems, it doesn't get much easier to solve when you increase the number of processers crunching away at the solution. The central technology device of this book, a computer with millions of processors, was put to work \\"breaking\\" ciphers by performing a search for the key with which they were encrypted.<br /><br />This is known as a brute force attack, and it does not scale well against even the cryptographic ciphers in use today. Brown is either misunderstanding or glossing over the fact that these brute force attacks are computationally \\"impossible.\\" That is to say, there will never be enough computers in the world to perform a brute force key search for keys as large as those mentioned in the book in a reasonable amount of time. Modern cryptography focuses on more interesting things like finding things like weaknesses in the chaining mechanism by which a cipher is applied repeatedly to a string of text. I find it amusing and disappointing that Brown's idea of what's going on behind the doors at the NSA is simply an absurdly powerful computer running at blinding speed, yet executing a primitive and doomed attempt at breaking a cipher.<br /><br />The cryptographic ideas in this book are rather weak, and perhaps that is the reason that most of the action centers around David Becker, a professor sent by Fletcher's boss to Spain to try to get the \\"key\\" to this impossible cipher from the man who wrote it. The best parts of this book -- the cat and mouse game between the professor and the assassin -- can also be found in Angels and Demons, and in my opinion, they are much more refined and well written in that book.<br /><br />The book is not bad, but it is not in the same league as his other novels.professor sent by Fletcher's boss to Spain to try to get the \\"key\\" to this impossible cipher from the man who wrote it. The best parts of this book -- the cat and mouse game between the professor and the assassin -- can also be found in Angels and Demons, and in my opinion, they are much more refined and well written in that book. <br /> <br />The book is not bad, but it is not in the same league as his other novels.

0671027387|4.0|I have read four of Dan Brown's novels now: The DaVinci Code, Angels and Demons, Digital Fortress, and Deception Point. Of the four, The DaVinci Code is my favorite, but this comes in a close second.<br /><br />Typical to all of his novels, the main characters in this book are constantly thrown into situations out of which there is no obvious escape, and they manage to save themselves by quick thinking and MacGuyver-like ingenuity.<br /><br />Dan Brown always chooses some well-defined academic category into which to immerse his plot. For Angels and Demons and The DaVinci Code, this was the idea of secret societies and what secret they might be guarding (The Illuminati in A&D, and The Priory of Sion in TDC). For Digital Fortress, he chose the science of cryptography, and for Deception Point, the plot is woven around the natural sciences related to meteorites.<br /><br />In Angels and Demons, and in The DaVinci Code, the main character is Robert Langdon, who doesn't necessarily have a lot of technical expertise in the central subject matter of the novel, but the reader is carried along with him as he learns about it from supporting characters and informational resources woven into the plotline.<br /><br />In Digital Fortress, the main character is described as already possessing a great deal of technical expertise in the central subject matter, cryptography. This departure from the style of guiding the reader through the learning process with the main character was something of a disappointment to me in Digital Fortress. Having taken courses in cryptography and being a computer programmer, it would have been quite interesting to me to see how he explored the subject from a learning point of view. However, in Digital Fortress, the main character is imbued with the technical knowledge from the outset, and her qualifications in this matter are described to great length, then subsequently ignored in the plot.<br /><br />In Deception Point, thankfully, Brown uses the approach of taking the reader along with the main character as she learns about the various sciences and technologies that surround the plot.<br /><br />The writing style is clear, and the detailed descriptions of the technologies and sciences surrounding the plot made me want to go find some textbooks on the subject and learn some more.<br /><br />The genre-typical habit of conducting several narratives simultaneously, divided into chapter segments which end on a cliffhanger, is well executed and makes it difficult to put the book down at the end of a chapter.<br /><br />The reason I give this four stars instead of five is this: I read this book last of the four Dan Brown books I have read, and certain plot elements are starting to seem a bit formulaic. Still, the predictability of certain plot devices does not detract much from the enjoyability of this book.the approach of taking the reader along with the main character as she learns about the various sciences and technologies that surround the plot. <br /> <br />The writing style is clear, and the detailed descriptions of the technologies and sciences surrounding the plot made me want to go find some textbooks on the subject and learn some more. <br /> <br />The genre-typical habit of conducting several narratives simultaneously, divided into chapter segments which end on a cliffhanger, is well executed and makes it difficult to put the book down at the end of a chapter. <br /> <br />The reason I give this four stars instead of five is this: I read this book last of the four Dan Brown books I have read, and certain plot elements are starting to seem a bit formulaic. Still, the predictability of certain plot devices does not detract much from the enjoyability of this book.

B000002572|5.0|Not only is Boston's self-titled debut the biggest selling debut album of all time but it's also one of the best classic rock albums ever released. Like other timeless albums such as Fleetwood Mac's Rumours and The Eagles' Hotel California, Boston plays like a greatest hits album as nearly every track here still gets regular airplay on classic rock radio.<br /><br />Every song here is top notch featuring memorable melodies, excellent harmonies, and stellar musicianship. The most well known track here is \\"More Than A Feeling\\" which not only became a Top 5 hit but is also one of the greatest songs in rock history. Like Led Zeppelin's \\"Stairway To Heaven\\", you recognize it immediately upon its acoustic guitar intro. The track \\"Hitch A Ride\\" continues in the same vein starting out as a soft ballad before gaining momentum during the solos. Bandleader Tom Scholz's solo during the song's outro is outstanding proving he's not only an excellent songwriter and producer but a great guitarist as well. \\"Foreplay/Long Time\\", which was a Top 20 hit, is also an outstanding track featuring a long organ solo from Scholz over the underrated rhythm section of bassist Fran Sheehan and drummer Sib Hashain before going into its memorable organ hook. The rockers \\"Something About You\\" and \\"Rock N' Roll Band\\" literally jump out of your speakers and still sound great nearly 30 years later. \\"Smokin'\\" is also a great track with its shuffle beat and organ solos from Scholz. Other great tracks here include \\"Peace Of Mind\\" and the closer \\"Let Me Take You Home Tonight.\\" Also worth noting is that while Scholz gets most of the credit for Boston's success, it's Brad Delp's vocals which truly bring these songs to life as his performance is on par with the best and more publicized vocalists of this era such as Journey's Steve Perry and Queen's Freddie Mercury. Boston is a timeless album that should be part of every music fan's collection. Highly recommended.

B00000DD2D|4.0|I've always been a bit sceptical about these superstar collaborations...they don't always work too well, and sometimes the guest stars overshadow the supposed main artist. But Jimmy Rogers and his various all-star combos manage to pull it off really well.    Sure, the arrangements are generally very similar all the way through, which does perhaps detract a little bit from an otherwise fine performance, but this is actually a very accessible and fun blues record. It doesn't just appeal to hard-core blues fans, more mainstream rock- and R&B lovers can certainly enjoy it as well, and Rogers and his guest musicians have hand-picked some real blues classics, and they generally do very well by them.    The album opens with a faithful take on Muddy Waters' \\"Blow Wind Blow\\", with excellent harmonica by the Fabulous Thunderbirds' Kim Wilson, and lead guitar by white blues-rock guitarist Jeff Healy.  Jimmy Rogers' own \\"Blues All Day Long\\" has Rogers sharing lead vocals with a certain Mr Eric Clapton, who also plays lead guitar. Carey Bell lends a hand on the harp.  On a gritty reading of the classic \\"Trouble No More\\", Rogers shares the lead vocals with Mick Jagger, and Keith Richards plays lead guitar.  \\"Bright Lights, Big City\\" is another Jimmy Rogers-original, with Taj Mahal behind the microphone (he is also featured on Rogers' \\"Ludella\\"), and Lowell Fulson appears along with harpist Carey Bell on Memphis Slim's \\"Everyday I Have The Blues\\".    The all-stars also do the inevitable take on Robert Johnson's \\"Sweet Home Chicago\\", with Stephen Stills (!) contributing lead guitar and co-lead vocals, and Stills pops up again on Big Maceo Merriweather's \\"Worried Life Blues\\".  Mick Jagger can't quite match Sonny Boy Williamson II on \\"Don't Start Me To Talkin'\\" (Keith Richards plays lead guitar again), but \\"Goin' Away Baby\\" is pretty well suited to his voice, and Eric Clapton and Jimmy Rogers do a fine rendition of Rogers' \\"That's All Right\\".    The album closes with an alternative rendition of John Lee Hooker's \\"Boom Boom\\" (retitled \\"Gonna Shoot You Right Down\\"), with - get this - Eric Clapton and Jimmy Page on guitars, and Robert Plant sharing lead vocal duties with Jimmy Rogers!  Rogers himself is in fine voice throughout, in spite of the fact that he was in his seventies at the time, and died before the album was released. The near-legendary blues- and R&B pianist Johnnie Johnson's dextrous playing belies his age. And finally, as a special treat for Hound Dog Taylor-nostalgics, the swivel chair is occupied by none other than the Houserockers' 66-year old drummer Ted Harvey.    Definitely recommended.
